An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Does the concept of a/an Algebraic Closure of Finite Field need to be defined for a definition of a/an Algebraic Element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of an Algebraic Element is defined within the context of any field extension $K \subset L$, where an element $\alpha \in L$ is considered algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies a polynomial equation with coefficients in $K$. This definition is general and applies to any fields $K$ and $L$, regardless of whether these fields are finite, infinite, algebraically closed, or not.

On the other hand, the concept of an Algebraic Closure of a Finite Field specifically pertains to the existence of a field that contains a given finite field and all its algebraic extensions. This concept is particularly relevant in the context of finite fields but is not necessary for the definition or understanding of what constitutes an algebraic element in a field extension.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of an algebraic element do not depend on the concept of an algebraic closure of a finite field. An algebraic element can be defined and understood entirely within the framework of field theory without reference to whether the fields involved have an algebraic closure or not.
